title: Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA)
description: Screens for mild cognitive impairment with assessment of multiple cognitive domains including attention, executive function, memory, language, visuospatial skills, abstraction, and orientation.

parameters.name: visuospatial_executive
parameters.description: Visuospatial/Executive Function: Alternating Trail Making Task (1 point), Cube Copy (1 point), Clock Drawing (3 points)

parameters.name: memory_registration
parameters.description: Memory Registration: 5 words (Face, Velvet, Church, Daisy, Red) - this score is not included in total but used for delayed recall

parameters.name: attention
parameters.description: Attention: Forward Digit Span (1 point), Backward Digit Span (1 point), Vigilance Task (1 point), Serial 7s (3 points)

parameters.name: language
parameters.description: Language: Sentence Repetition (2 points), Phonemic Fluency (1 point)

parameters.name: delayed_recall
parameters.description: Delayed Recall: 5 words with no cues (5 points)

parameters.name: orientation
parameters.description: Orientation: Date (1 point), Month (1 point), Year (1 point), Day (1 point), Place (1 point), City (1 point)

result.name: moca_score
result.description: MoCA total score ranging from 0-30 points (adjusted for education)

ranges.interpretation: Score indicates normal cognitive function. No cognitive impairment detected.
Score suggests possible mild cognitive impairment. Further evaluation and monitoring recommended.
Score indicates moderate cognitive impairment. Comprehensive evaluation and intervention needed.
Score suggests severe cognitive impairment. Immediate comprehensive evaluation and care planning required.

references: Nasreddine ZS, Phillips NA, Bédirian V, Charbonneau S, Whitehead V, Collin I, et al. The Montreal Cognitive Assessment, MoCA: a brief screening tool for mild cognitive impairment. J Am Geriatr Soc. 2005;53(4):695-9. doi: 10.1111/j.1532-5415.2005.53221.x.

Luis CA, Keegan AP, Mullan M. Cross validation of the Montreal Cognitive Assessment in community dwelling older adults residing in the Southeastern US. Int J Geriatr Psychiatry. 2009;24(2):197-201. doi: 10.1002/gps.2101.

Roalf DR, Moberg PJ, Xie SX, Wolk DA, Moelter ST, Arnold SE. Comparative accuracies of two common screening instruments for classification of Alzheimer's disease, mild cognitive impairment, and healthy aging. Alzheimers Dement. 2013;9(5):529-37. doi: 10.1016/j.jalz.2012.10.001.
formula: MoCA Score = Sum of domain scores (Visuospatial/Executive + Naming + Attention + Language + Abstraction + Delayed Recall + Orientation). Add 1 point if education ≤12 years. Maximum total: 30 points.
notes: More sensitive than MMSE for detecting mild cognitive impairment
Education adjustment: add 1 point if ≤12 years of formal education
Memory registration score not included in total (used for delayed recall only)
Available in multiple languages and versions
Should be administered by trained healthcare professionals
Visuospatial/Executive includes Trail Making, Cube Copy, Clock Drawing
Attention includes digit spans, vigilance, and serial 7 subtraction
Language includes sentence repetition and phonemic fluency
Abstraction tests similarities between word pairs
Delayed recall tests memory for 5 words after interference
Orientation tests temporal and spatial awareness
Widely used in clinical practice and research
Validated across multiple populations and cultures
